prompt:
You are provided with a list of characters, evidences and testimonies.
Characters:
Character 0
Name: Maya Fey
Description: My assistant and a disciple in the Kurain tradition of spirit channeling.
Character 1
Name: Pearl Fey
Description: Maya's cousin. A channeling prodigy with intense spiritual power. Also the youngest.
Character 2
Name: Will Powers
Description: Was the Steel Samurai. His face is a bit intimidating, so he's got hard luck in showbiz.
Character 3
Name: Security Lady
Description: Member of hotel security. I'm pretty sure her real name is Wendy Oldbag.
Character 4
Name: Lotta Hart
Description: Claims to be an investigative photographer. Latest field: the seedy world of tabloids.
Character 5
Name: Dick Gumshoe
Description: Detective at the local precinct. In charge of the initial investigation.
Character 6
Name: Juan Corrida
Description: The victim. A young star who played the Jammin' Ninja. Was on bad terms with Engarde.
Character 7
Name: Matt Engarde
Description: Popular young actor who plays the Nickel Samurai. Is rivals with the Jammin' Ninja.
Character 8
Name: Adrian Andrews
Description: Engarde's manager. An intelligent woman who seems to have it all together.
Character 9
Name: Franziska von Karma
Description: A prosecutor in Germany since age 13, she has come to America to defeat me in court.
Character 10
Name: Celeste Inpax
Description: Was Andrews' mentor and Corrida's manager. Killed herself two years ago.
Character 11
Name: Miles Edgeworth
Description: A gifted prosecutor. He disappeared suddenly a year ago.
Character 12
Name: John Doe
Description: The butler of Engarde Mansion. But for some reason, I get the feeling we've met before...
Character 13
Name: Shelly de Killer
Description: A professional assassin. Always leaves a Shelly card near his victim's body.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Attorney's Badge
Description: It's my all-important badge. It shows that I am a defense attorney.
Evidence 1
Name: Maya's Magatama
Description: Slightly translucent. It radiates softly with a mysterious light.
Evidence 2
Name: The Nickel Samurai
Description: A glossy photo Maya pushed onto me. A picture describing the nickel samurai costume.
Evidence 3
Name: Press Conference Ticket
Description: Seems like the Nickel Samurai is to confess something after the post-ceremony stage show.
Evidence 4
Name: Radio Transceiver
Description: Originally from the Bellboy. It can transmit and receive signals over great distances. Originally from Maya's kidnapper, who goes by the name of "De Killer".
Evidence 5
Name: Lotta's Camera
Description: A very expensive item valued at $1,600. It was stolen around the time of the murder. Stolen on the night of the murder. Tabloid article about the victim was in the case.
Evidence 6
Name: Hotel Guidemap
Description: Map of the Gatewater Hotel around the crime scene. A path from the west leads to the viola hall. To the north of the path is engarde and to the south corrida. East of viola hall is the lobby.
Evidence 7
Name: Guitar Case
Description: Found next to the victim. Empty. There is some water, but only on top of the lid. Empty. There is some water, but only on top of the lid. Bears only Corrida's fingerprints.
Evidence 8
Name: Wine Glass
Description: Found next to the victim. It's filled with tomato juice. No sign it's been drank. Found next to the victim. It's filled with tomato juice. Bears Andrews' fingerprints.
Evidence 9
Name: Crime Photo
Description: Photo of Juan Corrida's murder scene. [caption] The victim sits on a chair in a samurai outfit. There is a knife sticking out of his chest. A glass of juice sits behind him on the dresser. A full bottle of juice sits on the desk in front of him. An open guitar case lies on the floor next to him. Next to the guitar case are the remains of a smashed vase that has stained the carpet with water.
Evidence 10
Name: Autograph
Description: Juan Corrida's autograph. "To my dearest Wendy" is written on it.
Evidence 11
Name: Magazine Clipping
Description: An "article" from the tabloid "Gossip Land". The contents of the article follow: *Jammin' Midnight Rendezvous!?*

A super-star in an ultra-hot, mega-secret
love scandal!?

Reliable sources say that Juan Corrida
has been getting in close with the
mysterious, yet beautiful manager to the
stars, Ms. A.A.!

Evidence 12
Name: Suicide Report
Description: Deceased: Celeste InpaxFound by: Juan CorridaWas her suicide note hidden?
Evidence 13
Name: Attempted Suicide Report
Description: Attempter: Adrian AndrewsReason: Shock from Celeste Inpax's suicide.
Evidence 14
Name: Juan's Autopsy Report
Description: Time of death: 8:15 PMCause: Strangled to death with a scarf, then stabbed with a knife.
Evidence 15
Name: Knife
Description: Bears the victim's blood and Engarde's fingerprints. In the grip, "Gatewater" is engraved.
Gatewater Hotel
Evidence 16
Name: Jammin' Ninja's Button
Description: Was ripped from his costume. Is covered in Corrida's blood. Found in Engarde's "hakama".
Evidence 17
Name: Lotta's Photo
Description: Picture taken in the Hallway right after the murder. A person in samurai garb stands outside the door.
Evidence 18
Name: Picture Card
Description: Was placed next to the victim at the time of the murder. Ms. Andrews was carrying it.
Evidence 19
Name: Letter of Introduction
Description: Received from Edgeworth. Allows bearer to freely investigate the crime scene.
Evidence 20
Name: Matt's Note
Description: "Please feed my cat, Shoe. My house is just a little ways down from the hotel."
Evidence 21
Name: Spy Camera
Description: Set to record the victim's room from 8 PM for 1 hour. Was running at time of murder.
Evidence 22
Name: Transmitter
Description: Changes the footage taken by the spy camera into radio waves and transmits the data.
Evidence 23
Name: Stuffed Bear
Description: The spy camera was set in its right eye. Found in the victim's room.
Evidence 24
Name: Credit Card Receipt
Description: A receipt for $3,800. Proof Engarde bought a stuffed bear identical to one in evidence.
Evidence 25
Name: Figurine
Description: A wooden bear-shaped figurine. It's covered in many thin cuts. A wooden puzzle with a hollow inside. Only Corrida and Andrews know how to open it.
Evidence 26
Name: Celeste's Photo
Description: Found at Engarde Mansion. "With Love... Celeste" is written on it.
Evidence 27
Name: Celeste's Suicide Note
Description: Found inside the Figurine. It tells of Engarde's horrible misdeeds.
Evidence 28
Name: Pistol
Description: <if not asked for details> One of the items retrieved from De Killer's hideout. Nothing else is known.  <if asked for details> A small caliber pistol that is thought to have been fired by De Killer at Franziska.
Evidence 29
Name: Video Tape
Description: <if not asked for details> One of the items retrieved from De Killer's hideout. Nothing else is known.  <if asked for details> One of the items retrieved. De Killer violently tried to recover it. Contents unknown.
Evidence 30
Name: Bellboy's Uniform
Description: <if not asked for details> One of the items retrieved from De Killer's hideout. Nothing else is known.<if asked for details> Worn by De Killer on the night of the murder. One of its special buttons is missing.
Evidence 31
Name: Whip
Description: Thrown away by Franziska von Karma, it has a certain mysterious nostalgia to it.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: Matt Engarde and Juan Corrida were huge rivals with each other.
Person: Gumshoe
Testimony 1
Testimony: They each thought the other guy was "in his way". That's motive enough in my book.
Person: Gumshoe
Testimony 2
Testimony: As for evidence... There's the Jammin' Ninja's button.
Person: Gumshoe
Testimony 3
Testimony: It was ripped off of the ninja costume and was found in Mr. Engarde's "hakama".
Person: Gumshoe
Testimony 4
Testimony: The defendant's fingerprints were also all over the knife.
Person: Gumshoe
Testimony 5
Testimony: The defendant bought the knife for the crime... Which makes this a premeditated murder!
Person: Gumshoe

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Alright, so I'm trying to figure out which evidence and testimony contradict each other in this case. Let's start by looking at the testimonies and the evidence provided.

First, I see that Gumshoe testified about the rivalry between Matt Engarde and Juan Corrida, and he presented the Jammin' Ninja's button found in Engarde's "hakama" as evidence. He also mentioned that Engarde's fingerprints were on the knife, suggesting premeditation.

Looking at the evidence list, I notice that Evidence 16 is the Jammin' Ninja's Button, which was found in Engarde's "hakama" and is covered in Corrida's blood. This seems to support Gumshoe's testimony that Engarde was involved in the murder.

However, I also see that Evidence 14 is Juan's Autopsy Report, which states that the cause of death was strangulation with a scarf, followed by a stab wound. This suggests that the murder might have been more spontaneous rather than premeditated, which contradicts Gumshoe's claim of premeditation based on the knife purchase.

So, the testimony about premeditation using the knife as evidence (Testimony 5) doesn't align with the autopsy report indicating strangulation as the cause of death. This contradiction is important because it challenges the idea that the murder was planned in advance.

Therefore, the pair that contradicts each other is Evidence 14 and Testimony 5.
</think>

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Alright, I'm trying to figure out which evidence and testimony contradict each other in this case. Let's start by reviewing the evidence and testimonies provided.

First, I'll look at the evidence. There's a lot here, but some key pieces stand out. Evidence 15 is a knife found at the crime scene with the victim's blood and Matt Engarde's fingerprints. It also has "Gatewater" engraved on the grip, which suggests it's from the Gatewater Hotel where the murder took place. Then there's Evidence 16, a button from the Jammin' Ninja's costume, which was found in Engarde's "hakama." This seems like a direct link between Engarde and the victim, Juan Corrida.

Now, looking at the testimonies, Testimony 4 from Gumshoe states that the defendant's fingerprints were found on the knife, and Testimony 5 claims that the defendant bought the knife, making it a premeditated murder. This seems pretty damning for Engarde.

But wait, let's think about the timeline and the evidence. The autopsy report (Evidence 14) says Juan was strangled with a scarf before being stabbed. If Engarde bought the knife specifically for the murder, that would imply premeditation. However, the presence of the knife with his fingerprints and the button in his clothing suggests he was at the scene and involved in the crime.

However, I recall that there's also a Spy Camera (Evidence 21) and a Transmitter (Evidence 22) that were set up in the victim's room. This could mean that someone was monitoring the room remotely. If Engarde was being framed, maybe the real killer used the camera and transmitter to stage the crime and make it look like Engarde did it.

Additionally, there's a Magazine Clipping (Evidence 11) suggesting a secret relationship between Juan and Adrian Andrews, which could provide another motive. The fact that Andrews was found with a Picture Card (Evidence 18) next to the victim adds more complexity.

But focusing back on the knife and the testimonies, Gumshoe's Testimony 5 about the knife being bought for the crime directly ties Engarde to premeditation. However, the presence of the button in Engarde's clothing and the knife with his fingerprints seem to support this. Yet, if there's evidence of remote monitoring, it could imply that Engarde wasn't the one who actually committed the murder but was framed.

Wait, but the knife's engraving and the button are physical evidence directly linking Engarde to the crime scene. Unless there's evidence that someone else could have planted these items, they strongly suggest Engarde's involvement. The testimonies from Gumshoe align with these physical pieces of evidence, reinforcing the case against Engarde.

So, considering all this, I think the key contradiction might be between the physical evidence linking Engarde to the crime and any testimonies that suggest otherwise. But in this case, the testimonies support the evidence, so I might need to look for another contradiction.

Perhaps the Crime Photo (Evidence 9) shows a glass of tomato juice with Andrews' fingerprints, indicating she was present. If Andrews had a motive, as suggested by the magazine clipping, maybe she was involved. But the testimonies don't mention her as a suspect, focusing instead on Engarde.

Alternatively, the fact that the guitar case (Evidence 7) had water only on the lid might suggest it was placed there after the vase was smashed, indicating a setup. If Engarde was framed, this could contradict the testimonies that accuse him.

But overall, the most direct contradiction seems to be between the physical evidence (knife and button) and any potential alibis or alternative theories. However, since the testimonies provided don't offer an alibi for Engarde, I'll focus on the evidence that directly implicates him.

So, the knife with Engarde's fingerprints and the button in his clothing are strong evidence against him, aligning with the testimonies. Therefore, there might not be a direct contradiction unless there's evidence suggesting someone else was involved or that Engarde was framed.

Wait, but the Spy Camera and Transmitter could be used to monitor and potentially manipulate the crime scene, which might suggest a more complex setup. If someone else was using these devices, they could have orchestrated the murder to frame Engarde. This would contradict the testimonies that accuse Engarde based on the physical evidence.

In that case, the contradiction would be between the physical evidence pointing to Engarde and the possibility of being framed using the Spy Camera and Transmitter. However, without specific testimonies about the camera and transmitter, it's hard to make that connection.

Given the information, the most straightforward contradiction is between the physical evidence linking Engarde to the crime and any testimonies that might suggest otherwise. But since the testimonies support the evidence, I might need to reconsider.

Perhaps the key is that the knife was bought by Engarde, as per the Credit Card Receipt (Evidence 24), which matches the knife's engraving. This supports the testimony about premeditation. However, if the murder wasn't premeditated, this would contradict the testimony.

But the autopsy shows strangulation first, then stabbing, which might indicate a crime of passion rather than premeditation. This could contradict the testimony that it was premeditated.

So, the contradiction lies between the autopsy suggesting a possible crime of passion and the testimony claiming it was premeditated, supported by the knife purchase.
</think>

Testimony: He had to go to that post-ceremony stage show right after the crime, you know.
Person: Oldbag
Testimony 4
Testimony: So he must've worn that Nickel Samurai costume when he was stabbing poor Juan.
Person: Oldbag

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Alright, I'm trying to figure out which evidence and testimony contradict each other in this case. Let's start by understanding the context. The victim is Juan Corrida, who played the Jammin' Ninja, and the main suspect is Matt Engarde, who plays the Nickel Samurai. They were rivals, which gives Engarde a potential motive.

Looking at the testimonies, Oldbag mentions seeing someone in a Nickel Samurai costume coming out of Juan's room around the time of the murder. She specifically says it was Engarde wearing his flashy racing jacket. This seems to implicate Engarde directly, as it places him at the scene of the crime.

Now, examining the evidence, the crime photo (Evidence 9) shows the victim sitting in a samurai outfit with a knife in his chest, a glass of juice behind him, and an open guitar case with a smashed vase nearby. The guitar case is empty and has water only on the lid, which suggests it might have been used to carry something, but it's empty now.

The testimony mentions Engarde wearing the Nickel Samurai costume, but the crime photo shows the victim in a samurai outfit, not necessarily the Nickel Samurai. This could mean that Engarde was indeed at the scene, but the photo doesn't confirm he was wearing the specific Nickel Samurai costume as Oldbag testified. This discrepancy could be significant because it might question the reliability of Oldbag's testimony regarding the costume.

Additionally, the knife (Evidence 15) has Engarde's fingerprints, which directly links him to the crime. However, the testimony about the costume might be misleading if the photo doesn't show the Nickel Samurai outfit. This could mean that while Engarde was involved, the details about the costume might not be entirely accurate, which could affect the credibility of Oldbag's account.

So, the key contradiction here is between Oldbag's testimony about Engarde wearing the Nickel Samurai costume and the crime photo, which doesn't explicitly show that specific costume. This could indicate that Oldbag might have mistaken the costume or that Engarde was present but not necessarily wearing the Nickel Samurai outfit at the time of the murder.
</think>

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Alright, let's tackle this problem step by step. So, I'm given a list of characters, evidences, and testimonies related to a murder case, and I need to find a pair where the evidence and testimony contradict each other. I have to choose just one pair and present it in a specific JSON format.

First, I'll start by understanding the case. The victim is Juan Corrida, who played the Jammin' Ninja. The main suspect seems to be Matt Engarde, the Nickel Samurai, who was his rival. There are several pieces of evidence and testimonies from various characters involved.

Looking at the testimonies, I see that Adrian Andrews, Engarde's manager, testified about discovering Juan's body and the state of the crime scene. She mentioned that she saw the same scene as in the crime scene photo, which includes a glass of juice behind the victim, a full bottle of juice on the desk, an open guitar case, and a smashed vase staining the carpet with water.

Now, I'll examine the evidence. The crime scene photo (Evidence 9) shows the victim in a samurai outfit with a knife in his chest, a glass of juice behind him on the dresser, a full bottle of juice on the desk, an open guitar case, and a smashed vase next to it, which stained the carpet with water. Additionally, there's a wine glass (Evidence 8) found next to the victim filled with tomato juice, bearing Andrews' fingerprints.

In her testimony, Andrews admitted to pouring herself a glass of juice and knocking over the flower vase, which fell onto the guitar case. This explains the presence of the wine glass with her fingerprints and the water from the vase. However, the crime scene photo shows that the vase was already smashed when the photo was taken, which was right after the murder.

Here's where the contradiction arises. If Andrews knocked over the vase after discovering the body, the crime scene photo should show the vase intact because the photo was taken immediately after the murder. But the photo shows the vase already smashed, indicating that the vase was knocked over before Andrews arrived at the scene. This discrepancy suggests that Andrews might not have been telling the whole truth about her actions after discovering the body.

So, the evidence (the crime scene photo showing the smashed vase) contradicts the testimony (Andrews claiming she knocked over the vase after discovering the body). This contradiction could imply that Andrews might have been involved in the crime or at least was present earlier than she admitted.

Another point to consider is the knife (Evidence 15) found at the scene, which bears Engarde's fingerprints. This ties Engarde directly to the crime, supporting the idea that he might have been the one who actually committed the murder. However, since the question asks for a contradiction between evidence and testimony, the focus remains on Andrews' statement about the vase.

In summary, the crime scene photo (Evidence 9) contradicts Adrian Andrews' testimony (Testimony 5) because the photo shows the vase already smashed when she claimed to have knocked it over after discovering the body.
</think>

cot:
Alright, let's tackle this problem step by step. So, I need to find a pair consisting of one evidence and one testimony that contradict each other. The user has provided a list of characters, evidences, and testimonies, and I have to identify one such pair.

First, I'll start by understanding the scenario. It seems like a murder case involving several characters, with various pieces of evidence and testimonies provided. My task is to analyze these and find a contradiction between an evidence and a testimony.

Looking at the evidence list, I see Evidence 7 is a Guitar Case found next to the victim. It's described as empty, with water only on the lid, and it bears only Corrida's fingerprints. Now, moving to the testimonies, Testimony 3 from Adrian Andrews says, "And there was his dead body. I... I was in shock..." Testimony 4 adds, "What I saw was, naturally, the exact same scene as in the crime scene photo."

Now, the crime scene photo (Evidence 9) shows the victim in a samurai outfit with a knife in his chest, a glass of juice behind him, a full juice bottle on the desk, an open guitar case next to him, and a smashed vase staining the carpet with water.

In Testimony 5, Andrews says, "I was the one who knocked the flower vase over, where it fell onto the guitar case." This implies that the vase was knocked over, staining the carpet, and the guitar case was affected by the water.

However, Evidence 7 states that the guitar case has water only on the lid, not inside, and it's empty. Andrews' testimony suggests that the vase fell onto the guitar case, which would likely result in more water inside the case or at least more extensive water damage than just the lid.

This creates a contradiction because if the vase fell onto the guitar case, one would expect more water inside the case or more signs of water damage beyond just the lid. The evidence shows minimal water on the lid, which doesn't align with the testimony describing the vase falling onto the case.

Therefore, Evidence 7 (Guitar Case) contradicts Testimony 5 (Andrews' statement about knocking over the vase onto the guitar case).
</think>

cot:
Alright, I need to figure out which evidence and testimony contradict each other in this case. Let's start by reviewing the evidence and testimonies provided.

First, looking at the evidence, there's a piece called "Guitar Case" (Evidence 7). It's described as being found next to the victim, empty, with water only on the lid. It bears only Corrida's fingerprints. This suggests that the case was opened, but nothing was taken, and only the victim handled it.

Now, examining the testimonies, Adrian Andrews mentions in Testimony 5 that the Jammin' Ninja's button was torn off during a fight with Matt Engarde. She claims this button is evidence of the struggle between the two. However, the Guitar Case evidence shows that it was only Corrida's fingerprints on it, indicating that he was the one who opened it, not Engarde. This contradicts Andrews' testimony because if Engarde had been involved in a fight and torn the button, one might expect his fingerprints to be on the guitar case as well. Since only Corrida's fingerprints are present, it suggests that Engarde wasn't involved in handling the case, which undermines Andrews' claim about the fight and the button being evidence of Engarde's guilt.

Therefore, the contradiction lies between Evidence 7 (Guitar Case) and Testimony 5.

cot:
Alright, so I'm trying to figure out which evidence and testimony contradict each other in this case. Let's see, the user has provided a detailed list of characters, evidences, and testimonies related to a murder investigation. My task is to identify one pair where the evidence and testimony don't align or directly oppose each other.

First, I'll start by understanding the context. The victim is Juan Corrida, who played the Jammin' Ninja, and the main suspect is Matt Engarde, who plays the Nickel Samurai. They were rivals, which gives Engarde a potential motive. The crime scene is in a hotel, and there are several pieces of evidence and testimonies from various characters.

Looking at the testimonies, Adrian Andrews, who is Engarde's manager, provides some statements. Specifically, in Testimony 5, she mentions that she knocked over a flower vase, which spilled water onto the guitar case. This seems to explain the presence of water on the guitar case.

Now, examining the evidence, the Guitar Case (Evidence 7) is described as being empty with water only on the lid, and it bears only Corrida's fingerprints. Andrews claims she knocked over the vase, causing water to spill on the case. However, the evidence shows that the guitar case was empty and had water only on the lid, which aligns with her testimony about the vase.

But wait, there's another testimony from Andrews. In Testimony 4, she states that she poured herself a glass of juice because she felt faint. The Wine Glass (Evidence 8) found at the scene is filled with tomato juice and bears her fingerprints, which supports her claim. However, she also mentions that she thought Corrida had fainted, not realizing he was dead until later. This doesn't directly contradict the evidence but adds context to her actions.

Another point of interest is the presence of the Jammin' Ninja's Button (Evidence 16) found in Engarde's "hakama." This suggests a struggle between Corrida and Engarde, supporting the idea that Engarde was at the scene and had a motive. However, Andrews' testimonies don't directly contradict this evidence; instead, they provide additional context about her own actions.

I also notice that the Crime Photo (Evidence 9) shows the victim sitting in a samurai outfit with a knife in his chest, a glass of juice behind him, and an open guitar case with a smashed vase nearby. Andrews' testimony about knocking over the vase and pouring juice fits into this scene, but the evidence doesn't contradict her account.

Considering all this, the most direct contradiction seems to be between Evidence 7 (Guitar Case) and Testimony 5. Andrews admits to knocking over the vase, which explains the water on the guitar case. However, the evidence shows that the guitar case was empty, which might imply that she didn't open it, contradicting her testimony about opening it after the vase was knocked over.

Wait, no—Testimony 5 is about her knocking over the vase, which caused water to spill on the guitar case. The evidence shows water only on the lid, which aligns with her action. So maybe there's no contradiction there.

Looking back, perhaps the contradiction lies elsewhere. For instance, Andrews claims she didn't kill Corrida and was merely in shock, but the evidence points to Engarde. However, the question is about a specific evidence-testimony pair.

Upon reviewing, the initial assessment seems correct: Evidence 7 (Guitar Case) and Testimony 5 (Andrews knocking over the vase) don't contradict each other. Instead, they support the same scenario.

Maybe I need to look for a different pair. Let's consider the Wine Glass (Evidence 8) and Testimony 4. Andrews says she poured juice for herself, and the evidence shows a glass with tomato juice and her fingerprints. This supports her testimony, so no contradiction there.

Another angle: The Knife (Evidence 15) has Engarde's fingerprints, suggesting he stabbed Corrida. Andrews' testimonies don't directly contradict this; instead, they focus on her own actions.

Perhaps the contradiction is more about the timing or the presence of Engarde at the scene. The Lotta's Photo (Evidence 17) shows someone in samurai garb outside the door, which could be Engarde. If Andrews testified that Engarde was elsewhere, that would be a contradiction. However, her testimonies don't provide an alibi for Engarde.

In conclusion, the most straightforward contradiction is between the presence of water on the guitar case (Evidence 7) and Andrews' testimony about opening it (Testimony 5), as the evidence shows the case was empty and only the lid was wet, implying she didn't open it as she claimed.
